nodes.text: Absolute income mobility in the United States has declined since 1940 and restoring mid-20th-century rates would require economic growth that is shared more broadly across the income distribution

We estimate cohort-specific absolute mobility Ac as the fraction of children earning weakly more than their parents using Ac = integral 1{Qk_c(rk) >= Qp_c(rp)} Cc(rk,rp) drk drp, where Qk and Qp are marginal quantiles and Cc is the copula of ranks

Data sources: children marginal distributions from CPS March supplements (1970-2014), parents marginal distributions from pooled decennial censuses (IPUMS 1% and 5%), and copula for 1980-1982 cohorts from de-identified tax records linking >10 million parent-child pairs

For cohorts lacking direct panel copula data (pre-1980), we (i) use a benchmark assuming copula stability based on evidence since 1970 and (ii) compute tight nonparametric upper and lower bounds on Ac by linear programming searching over all copulas satisfying first-order stochastic dominance and integration constraints

Baseline measurement choices: pretax family income at age 30 in 2014 dollars using CPI-U-RS; parents and children incomes measured consistently across cohorts with sensitivity checks for taxes/transfers, age 40, family-size adjustment, and individual income

Main empirical result: Under benchmark copula stability, fraction of children earning more than their parents fell from about 92% for the 1940 birth cohort to about 50% for the 1984 birth cohort; bounds relaxing copula stability give 1940 cohort between 84% and 98%

Decline concentrated across the income distribution with largest drops in middle and upper-middle parent percentiles (e.g., 50th percentile: 93% to 45%; 90th percentile: 88% to 33%) and geographically widespread across states

Sensitivity analyses: alternative inflation indices, adjusting for taxes and transfers, measuring income at age 40, dividing by square root of family size, individual earnings comparisons, and plausible income upward adjustments yield qualitatively similar declines in absolute mobility

Counterfactual simulations: (A) "Higher GDP growth" where 1980 cohort experiences 1940-era per-family GDP growth but 2010 income shares yields mean absolute mobility ~62%; (B) "More broadly shared growth" where 2010 GDP allocated by 1940 income shares yields mean absolute mobility ~80%

Interpretation of counterfactuals: Increasing aggregate growth alone (with current unequal distribution) produces modest gains in absolute mobility and would require unrealistically high sustained growth (>5% per family per year) to restore 1940s rates; redistributing existing growth more broadly can reverse most of the decline

Mechanism: Because recent GDP growth is concentrated among high-income households, additional GDP disproportionately benefits a small share of families and thus has limited effect on the fraction of children who out-earn their parents

Conclusion: The long-run decline in absolute mobility is mainly driven by a more unequal distribution of economic growth rather than solely slower aggregate growth, implying policy aiming to revive high absolute mobility must promote broadly shared gains across the income distribution

Limitation: Copula (relative mobility) is directly observed only for cohorts since 1971; for earlier cohorts we rely on copula stability benchmark and linear-program bounds which are tight for early cohorts but less informative for the most recent cohorts where overlap between parent and child distributions is greater
